articles.headline: Conquering Android’s World of Themes
articles.snippet: An app cuts out the technical gobbledygook and presents smartphone users with a clear path to their own identity.
articles.abstract: An app cuts out the technical gobbledygook and presents smartphone users with a clear path to their own identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I ditched my iPhone 4S for an HTC One, and now I think the difference between the world’s most popular smartphone operating systems — Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android — can be explained with a metaphor about home decorating.

articles.headline: A Fisherman in New York’s Sea of Faces
articles.snippet: Brandon Stanton’s new book of 400 photographic portraits, “Humans of New York,” has become a best seller.
articles.abstract: Brandon Stanton’s new book of 400 photographic portraits, “Humans of New York,” has become a best seller.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s how Brandon Stanton spends several hours each day: He walks up to total strangers in New York City, requests permission to take their pictures and then asks questions so personal they might make Oprah Winfrey blush.

articles.headline: Twitter Prices Its Initial Offering at $26 Per Share
articles.snippet: Twitter’s initial public offering, which values the company at roughly $18 billion, is a sign of its maturity, even as it combats slowing growth.
articles.abstract: Twitter’s initial public offering, which values the company at roughly $18 billion, is a sign of its maturity, even as it combats slowing growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter, long protected in its Silicon Valley nest, is about to venture into the more unforgiving world of Wall Street.

articles.headline: Twitter’s Market Valuation Suggests Wall St. Sees Huge Growth Potential
articles.snippet: Investors are betting that Twitter will become wildly profitable as advertisers pay it increasing amounts of money to reach consumers who use the service.
articles.abstract: Investors are betting that Twitter will become wildly profitable as advertisers pay it increasing amounts of money to reach consumers who use the service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter is a young company generating large losses as it competes in a highly uncertain sector of the economy.

articles.headline: China Wants Its Movies to Be Big in the U.S., Too
articles.snippet: China’s ambitious new film entrepreneurs, dozens of whom gathered in California this week for industry events, want something that has largely eluded them: a homemade global hit.
articles.abstract: China’s ambitious new film entrepreneurs, dozens of whom gathered in California this week for industry events, want something that has largely eluded them: a homemade global hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Investment capital? They’re loaded.

articles.headline: An Offer From Amazon to Its Most Bitter Rivals
articles.snippet: The giant retailer announced a program to pay independent bookstores to sell its e-books and popular reading devices.
articles.abstract: The giant retailer announced a program to pay independent bookstores to sell its e-books and popular reading devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon is going to the people who dislike and fear it the most — independent bookstore owners — and offering to work together to fulfill the needs and desires of their customers.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: G.O.P. Weighs Limiting Clout of Right Wing
articles.snippet: Leaders of the Republican establishment are pushing their party to rethink how it chooses nominees and advocating changes they say would result in less extreme contenders.
articles.abstract: Leaders of the Republican establishment are pushing their party to rethink how it chooses nominees and advocating changes they say would result in less extreme contenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leaders of the Republican establishment, alarmed by the emergence of far-right and often unpredictable Tea Party candidates, are pushing their party to rethink how it chooses nominees and advocating changes they say would result in the selection of less extreme contenders.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Mannequins Give Shape to a Venezuelan Fantasy
articles.snippet: Mannequins with bulging bosoms have become standard in Venezuela, reflecting the country’s embrace of plastic surgery even among those who can least afford it.
articles.abstract: Mannequins with bulging bosoms have become standard in Venezuela, reflecting the country’s embrace of plastic surgery even among those who can least afford it.
articles.lead_paragraph: VALENCIA, Venezuela — Frustrated with the modest sales at his small mannequin factory, Eliezer Álvarez made a simple observation: Venezuelan women were increasingly using plastic surgery to transform their bodies, yet the mannequins in clothing stores did not reflect these new, often extreme proportions.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Is Said to Pay AT&T for Call Data
articles.snippet: The disclosure shows that agencies beyond the N.S.A. exploit call metadata with programs regulated by an inconsistent patchwork of legal standards, procedures and oversight.
articles.abstract: The disclosure shows that agencies beyond the N.S.A. exploit call metadata with programs regulated by an inconsistent patchwork of legal standards, procedures and oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. is paying AT&T more than $10 million a year to assist with overseas counterterrorism investigations by exploiting the company’s vast database of phone records, which includes Americans’ international calls, according to government officials.

articles.headline: Growth Gain Blurs Signs of Weakness in Economy
articles.snippet: Five years after the global economy was falling the fastest, Western economies are still failing to gain much-needed momentum, despite the efforts of central bankers on both sides of the Atlantic.
articles.abstract: Five years after the global economy was falling the fastest, Western economies are still failing to gain much-needed momentum, despite the efforts of central bankers on both sides of the Atlantic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years after the global economy was falling at its fastest rate, Western economies are still failing to gain much-needed momentum, despite the efforts of central bankers on both sides of the Atlantic.
